facts.fact: On July 4, 1918, legendary England seamer Alec Bedser was born. He went on to become one of the finest post-war bowlers for England, taking 236 Test wickets.
Former England cricketer Jan Brittin, the highest run-scorer in women's Test cricket with 1,935 runs, was born on July 4, 1959.
On July 4, 1984, West Indian all-rounder Alvin Kallicharran smashed 206 runs and took 6 wickets in a NatWest Trophy match for Warwickshire against Oxfordshire.
On July 4, 1986, England's Mike Gatting scored an unbeaten 183 in a Test match against India at Edgbaston, contributing to a significant innings for England.
Indian batting maestro Sachin Tendulkar scored an unbeaten 122 against West Indies in the Coca-Cola Cup in Harare on July 4, 2001, leading India to a six-wicket victory.

script:
Hey cricket fans, ever wonder about the magic moments etched in history? Let's dive into some incredible feats from July 4th!

First up, a pioneer in women's cricket. On this day in 1959, Jan Brittin was born. She wasn't just any player; she became the highest run-scorer in women's Test cricket, with an incredible 1,935 runs! A true legend who paved the way for many.

Then, talk about an all-round masterclass! On July 4, 1984, West Indian great Alvin Kallicharran unleashed an unbelievable performance. Playing for Warwickshire, he not only smashed 206 runs but also grabbed 6 wickets in the same NatWest Trophy match against Oxfordshire! That's a rare double-punch of pure dominance!

And finally, the Master Blaster himself. On July 4, 2001, Sachin Tendulkar showed why he's a legend. He scored an unbeaten 122 against West Indies in the Coca-Cola Cup in Harare, guiding India to a six-wicket victory. Classic Sachin, leading from the front!

Which of these legendary moments do you remember most?
